article_title: Pelzman's Picks: Penalized for Ordering PSA Tests?
article_text:
The use of antibiotics in the last weeks of life needs a second look, Manisha Juthani-Mehta, MD, and colleagues, write in JAMA ~ Antimicrobials at the End of Life: An Opportunity to Improve Palliative Care and Infection Management

U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations based on letter grade could be misinterpreted in light of Affordable Care Act coverage, Albert L. Siu, MD, MSPH, and colleagues, write in JAMA ~ Evidence-Based Clinical Prevention in the Era of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act: The Role of the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force

The CMS has proposed a "quality" measure to censure docs for ordering unnecessary PSA tests, Melinda Beck reports in the WSJ ~ Doctors Could be Penalized for Ordering Prostate Tests

Fewer PSA screening tests have, not surprisingly, resulted in fewer men being diagnosed with prostate cancer, Melinda Beck reports for the WSJ ~ Fewer Men Diagnosed With Prostate Cancer

Removing the confidentiality safeguard would do more harm than good, Sandeep Jauhar, MD, writes in a NYT Op-Ed ~ Protect Doctor-Patient Confidentiality

Hayward Zwerling, MD, offers a long list of reasons to drop the Meaningful Use program in The Health Care Blog ~ 25 Reasons It is Time to Kill Meaningful Use

Primary care practices are becoming "command centers," according to financial consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers survey results, Neil Versel writes in MedCity News ~ 7 things about digital health from PwC's report on primary care

Fred N. Pelzman, MD, of Weill Cornell Internal Medicine Associates and weekly blogger for MedPage Today, follows what's going on in the world of primary care medicine. Pelzman's Picks is a compilation of links to blogs, articles, tweets, journal studies, opinion pieces, and news briefs related to primary care that caught his eye.
